intro: Phaeopappus cheirolophus, commonly known as the red-hairy pappus, is a species of flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It is characterized by its distinctive red, hairy pappus that aids in wind dispersal of its seeds. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments. Its leaves are often covered in fine hairs, which help reduce water loss. It produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in the spring, contributing to its ecological role in pollination and seed dispersal.
